headline: Grandma's Homemade Noodles
description: A homemade noodle recipe for perfect egg noodles made from egg, salt, milk, flour, and baking powder. You'll love how they taste in soups and broths.

video.description: See how to make homemade soup noodles.
video.name: Grandma’s Noodles II

name: Grandma's Homemade Noodles
recipeIngredient: 1 cup sifted all-purpose flour, or more as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Combine egg, milk, and salt in a bowl. Add sifted flour and stir until a dough forms, adding more flour as needed, a little at a time, for the dough to come together. Separate into two balls.
Sprinkle a work surface with flour and roll out each piece of dough as thin as you like. Let rolled dough rest for 20 minutes.
Cut into strips and spread to dry, dusting with a bit of flour so the noodles don't stick together. Let dry for approximately 2 hours.
Cook noodles in boiling salted water, or hot soup, until tender, about 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: My mother taught me to make a well in the flour and then add the liquid ingredients. Then bring in the flour from the outside gradually. My grandma's noodles were rolled and cut thick like Reames noodles. That is what we all remember...especially over mashed potatoes. I will try this with the baking powder and see what happens but the recipe sounds spot on as is. My grandma also told my mother that her secret was adding water to the dough. We called them tough noodles.
Great recipe but for my family I double and sometimes triple the recipe.
I added the noodles from this recipe to my tomato beef soup. Superb!
Easy to do used a bowl to help keep ingredients from running. Roll out on cookie sheet or counter. Make sure to roll thin they swell up in water, add some bouillon to boiling water. Easy peasy

Freaking amazing!! Though it was so easy to make them, I am so impressed with myself and my husband said he’s blown away ?? I didn’t change one thing. I did use a lot of flour and rolled out in between parchment paper.
My family loved it. I'm going to make again.
I’ll recipes please please please please start providing week measurements for bulk ingredients such as flour and sugar FYI fantastic I think it’s the baking powder i scaled up to 16 servings

I used to get a turkey noodle soup from a restaurant I worked at back in the late 80's called Bakers Square here in SoCal. It was the only place that make nice thick noodles like these and the mouth-feel was delightful for a poultry soup. 

The comment to use cake flour is def. a good one for these. If you like a clear broth I also recommend making and straining your soup stock and vegetables into a separate pot and boil your noodles in salted water separately. Drain and Rinse them with cold water to prevent sticking together and then keep in a zip lock or Tupperware until ready to place into the dinner bowls. This keeps your broth from getting too starchy and changing the soup into an undesirable milky floury broth.
Easy and tastes great! I used to buy frozen noodles but then started cooking gluten free. I just swapout Krustee’s gluten free flour In this recipe and it’s awesome!
Delicious and easy to make.

#1 = Not sure if I did something wrong or right; but this is hardly enough to feed 4 people. 

#2 = Made them exactly as the recipe is written and wouldn't change a thing besides quadrupling the batch. 

#3 = Rolling pin and pizza cutter are a must.
Did not make any changes. Great noodles
Exact recipe my Mom used. Easy and delicious.
Very easy. Wasn't terrible hand rolling either. I have tried other recipes and hand rolled those, this one was by far the easiest.
This was really delicious. I followed the directly completely. I don't think it's mentioned here how many servings this makes but in my opinion, it makes enough noodles for 2 people.
did not make any changes but did triple the recipe cause our family loves noodles. Will definitely use this again and again. Thanks.

I had to add some more eggs to the dough, it was getting dry. I rolled it out and cut it into 1/4 inch strips and dried them. I put them in a plastic bag and saved them for later use. I did make some soup out of some of them later and they tasted good. So I will use this recipe again.
We cut them into little bite-size pieces. Dropped them in our homemade soup, and it was delicious!
Made noodles for chicken noodle soup. My husband raved about it.
I made this and the noodles were great.
My favorite and go to noodle recipe. Never had an issue and it os a family favorite for sure. I always have to double or triple the recipe! It is THAT good.
Easy, doubled the recipe, did not use baking powder. Definitely my go to noodle recipe Family loved them!
Instead of using chicken, I used turkey then I made gravy out of the turkey broth, with some homemade mashed potatoes. Yum
I made this last night. delicious. I followed the recipe exactly except..... I did not let it sit for two hours. I used it maybe 30 minutes after I cut them. I WILL make this again and again!.

I haven't made this yet but it looks authentic, without the optional baking powder. Add the baking powder and they rise and become biscuits, not noodles. Make them larger and they become dumplings, which are actually large noodles in sauce/gravy. I will try this recipe (sans the baking powder).

I made this exactly as shown in the recipe. I mixed the ingredients in my Kitchenaid just out of laziness. I used a manual pasta roller to roll the dough to the "4" setting, then ran it thru the fettuccine cutters. The noodles came out perfect. Not too thick, not too chewy, and they didn't become soggy in the leftover chicken noodle soup. 10/10, will make again!

Overall, this worked pretty well for me. It was quick and simple to throw together. Unlike other posters, I had no issues getting everything together by hand without any machinery. It readily formed a ball and then I kneaded for a few minutes, rolled it, and done. I did have to add an extra tbsp of milk to get a noodle consistency on the dough. It came together fine without it, but it was a bit dry. To be fair though I think that's more a function of dry winter months than the recipe itself.

I wish I could get these a little thinner. I actually had to keep adding liquid so that I could get these to stick together. Then I kneaded until the liquid was incorporated. It probably took one more tablespoon (I used water). I strongly suggest boiling in salted water before adding to your soup. They have a great flavor. Reminds me of my polish Grandma!
Make them quite often they are great noodles.
Very nice texture. Noodle were firm and tasted good!
I enjoyed making the noodles from scratch. My chicken vegetable soup was out of this world and these noodles put it over the top !
I always use this recipe when I make chicken and noodles, it is super easy and great. You don't have to let the noodles dry if you are in a hurry

Made 4 batches of these noodles for chicken soup. Very easy and delicious. I added a little more milk as my dough was a little dry. That may be because my eggs didn’t have enough liquid. The noodles got better the longer they stayed in the soup. Never mushy - a great texture - just fantastic!
Nice easy recipe for homemade noodles. Reminds me of my Grandma's! We couldn't wait for them to dry. Fine without.
This is the same recipe that my mother-in-law used to make. I don’t have a fancy machine to use so I do it the was I was taught. By hand. I love the way they turn out. My family loves them.
This turned out so good. Simple and yummy!

I think I need some advice with this recipe. No matter how many times I try this with the listed ingredients, I can’t get the dough to come together. I’ve tried mixing by hand, in the stand mixer and food processor. To avoid over-working the dough, I always end up adding more liquid. While they still taste great, that makes cutting the softer noodles more difficult. What could I be doing wrong?! I’m not a novice cook or baker but I struggle with this one!
Will definitely make again!

I made it in my Kitchenaid and everybody loved it. My noodles were comically huge (because I got carried away with the baking powder). But they were still yummy. I doubled the recipe mixed salt, pepper and the baking powder in with the flour and then instead of milk I used condensed milk because that's what I had on hand. I didn't have any flour left over to roll them out with. So I used Bisquick I had on hand. They turned out great!
I think they turned out fine.. I don't use any gadgets just a flour sifter and my hands.. Easy to make taste good.
Simple straight forward noodle

So delicious and takes me back to my childhood memories of Mom making noodles and drying them over a broom handle balanced over the back of two chairs. Made them for the Chicken and Spaetzle soup. Left out the Spaetzle dumplings and used these instead. Makes the perfect amount.

This is a great basic noodle recipe that you can place in any soup - I like to use it in chicken soup instead of using egg noodles that get mushy after a while. I like to cut the noodles really thick so they are still firm after a couple of days in the fridge. They are approximately the size and shape of I love cooking ahead and having leftovers for busy days!

They turn out great! I use a noodle press and I roll them out first as thin as possible. No baking powder. Second time using this recipe and they are awesome. So much better than crunchy store bought noodles. Worth the work!

I love how easy it was. I didn't realize that the recipe says to let the noodles dry for 2 hours. I put the noodles in front of a fan for about 15 min. Then threw them in my soup to boil for 10 min. I made more noodles and just threw them in to boil for 10 min. They were both good a little different texture. 
I used Baking soda... It made the noodles bubble up. YUMMY. My kiddos loved it.
Best homemade noodles for homemade chicken noodle soup!
Hey Sandy, Tell your grandma THANK YOU from Robert!
Easy.....taste like home when we were kids.
They were perfect!
This is the first time I have made homemade noodles. This recipe was easy and they turned out great. I didn't use the baking powder. This is definitely a favorite and will make them often!!

I have made homemade chicken and noodles for years. They have become our families traditional Christmas since my children were little and now I make them for my grandchildren. After all the work leading up to Christmas this simple meal is one we all love and it is so much easier on the cook than a fancy dinner. I added the baking powder this year and was very happy with the result. Sometimes my noodles were a little tough but the baking powder lightened them up. I always make several batches for my family as one is never enough.

I was fairly confused by the consistency of the dough initially. I mixed the flour and baking powder, combined everything else in a different bowl, then gradually added the dry ingredients to the wet. What I ended up with was so wet that it wasn't even slightly ready to be rolled. I ended having to add quite a lot more flour before I had a workable ball of dough. At that point the rolling, cutting, waiting, (shorter) drying, and cooking all went fairly easily. The problem was the flavor was definitely much more noticeably floury and the egg gets kinda lost.

I tried two batches, got the same results. Based on reading other reviews, I feel like I must be doing something wrong. It seems like the majority of people had a good ball of dough with very little work. I ended up with a puddle of dough.

Gonna try it again, but next time I'm going to cut the milk down to 2 tsp and see what happens.
Perfect! I added Italian seasoning and tripled the recipe. I used a third of them for a casarole and I froze the rest. No need for drying before cooking or freezing. Excellent recipe!

These noodles were a fairly simple recipe and they tasted great! I had to quadruple the recipe to make as much as i needed but it worked well. Only special item i had to use was sifter. A mixer could be useful but uneeded if you don't mind getting your hands dirty

Fantastic!! I had never made noodles before in my life and these turned out amazing. I am definitely going to continue to make my own noodles from now on. I made them to put in turkey soup after Thanksgiving. So easy, and so delicious.
I prepared this recipe exactly as written, using my food processor. Perfection.
no changes and yes I surely make it again

So sorry. I'm about to tell you all the changes I made. Fair warning to all you who hate us recipe tweakers. I tripled this recipe for 7 people. I did 2 medium eggs, 4 medium egg yolks, and 2 small glugs of olive oil (maybe 2 T). No milk. It ended up extra tough, so I added maybe 1/4 - 1/3 cup water. It was SO lovely. The noodles had so much rich flavor from the egg yolks, and I loved how the noodles puffed up from the baking powder. Thanks for the basic recipe to give me the confidence to try making my own noodles for the first time. We LOVED them. BTW, we just served them tossed with butter and salt and pepper, so we could really taste the flavor.
I love this recipe. Simplicity is key.
no changes, recipe outstanding

Did they say it would be easy? It was. Did they say it would be delicious? Probably. Did they say I would make it again and again? No, but I did and will. There is nothing like a chicken soup with big chewy golden noodles. Don’t be afraid. It really is easy.

I followed the recipe without the baking powder. 1st time making homemade noodles and this was easy and good. The recipe makes a small batch so for soup I would double it. Rolled out between 2 sheets of was paper.

I disagree with some of the reviews saying you need a bunch of tools to make the noodles properly. I made them with all the ingredients and my bare-hands to mix it all together. They came out great and puffed up when I added them to my soup. The taste nice too!
YOU CAN ALSO ROLL THE DOUGH UP LIKE A JELLYROLL AND CUT THE NOODLES THAT WAY VERY EASY RECIPE

I don't get the person that said you need fancy kitchen equipment to make these noodles. I have no fancy kitchen equipment and make these by hand in an ordinary mixing bowl, roll them out, and cut them by hand. Love this easy recipe. My 2nd time making them and they turned out perfect both times. This will always be my go to noodle recipe. Turned out perfect in my home made chicken noodle soup. I got rave reviews!

I use this every time I make beef and noodles, chicken n noodles, chicken dumplings. it's great! I leave the dough a little thicker for dumplings and I add pepper and sage for extra flavor. The recipe is easy to modify for your family size! Thanks for allowing myself and others to enjoy this!
I made these the other night and it took me back to my childhood. I had been looking for this recipe since my mom passed away. These are the best! Will definitely be making them often!

These noodles were awesome and super easy to make. The noodles came out light and fluffy. I did increase the baking powder to a heaping teaspoon but that was the only change I made to the recipe. This recipe is now my favorite go to noodle recipe. Thank you so much for sharing.

I love these noodles, I of course have to double/triple everything because I'm cookongvfor a family of 6 but these are great & easy! I make them by hand I did not use any processor, mixer, ect simply because I don't own them. I think it takes the love out lol. But anyways these are great noodles ??

Turns out I'm a bit of disaster when it comes to making noodles but what I ended up with was delicious! Maybe double the recipe - I wished I had more. As for tricks and tips, read others' reviews and/or watch the video. As for me... I need to hone my skills... off to make another batch... :)
This was an easy and delicious recipe. Loved the way they turned out.

I cook these in homemade chicken stock made from a whole fat hen, onion, celery, carrots, a bay leaf, salt, pepper and water to cover. Strain it and cook the noodles in this rich and delicious broth. I add three or so cans of cream of chicken soup to help to thicken the broth in the final minutes of cooking. I make six batches of these tender and delicious noodles for about thirty people for Thanksgiving or Christmas dinner. We have lots of food but the noodles are everyone's favorite.
Have made this a few times and really like it, just the way it is written. Did double the batch to feed hungry guys.

First time pasta-maker here. No fancy tools, just a rolling pin, a food processor, and a large kitchen knife. EASY recipe and VERY tasty. Made the Eggplant Bolognese to go with it. *NOTES* I tried a few different flour combos and with/without baking powder. Did not care for the semolina but may experiment a lower percentage, as I read somewhere that if you're planning to freeze the pasta, adding semolina is best to maintain the integrity of the pasta. Also, the baking powder (optional ingredient) lightens the dough *slightly*, making the cooked product slightly less rubbery. Both ways are EXCELLENT.

Excellent meaty noodles for chicken noodle soup! I opted to leave the baking soda out so they would be more dense. Also used food processor like other reviewer which worked well on pulse just until it comes together into one ball. Won't be disappointed.
Wonderful. I put in my pasta machine with these exact ingredients. I used the fettuccini past cutter and added to my homemade chicken soup. Wonderful!

I made this with all-purpose Gluten-free baking flour by Bob's Red Mill. I made two batches, using the food processor, as one reviewer suggested. I followed the recipe for the first batch, except using 1/2 the salt & baking powder. It seemed VERY dry & barely held together. For the 2nd batch I added 1 T of milk, keeping the rest the same. Still a bit dry, but more cohesive. Both cooked up well & were indistinguishable form each other in the end. They were a hit! I am sure I will be making them again soon :)

I would give this recipe 4.5 stars! Super easy and they were delicious. I didn't know this was so easy! I followed 2 other reviewers suggestions and used only 1/4 tsp of baking powder. I didn't wait for them to dry, but I did allow them to rest for 20 minutes. Then I cooked the noodles in a separate pot of boiling salted water for ten minutes before adding to my soup; then low simmered in the soup pot for another 15 minutes .

Also, I decided to use 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour and 1/2 cup of white flour and it turned out great! (I don't usually like whole wheat pasta).

GREAT RECIPE!! I made the recipe just as it is written. After rolling out dough, I cut the dough into 1/2" squares, put them in hot chicken broth simmering on the stove, and let the square noodles cook for 10 mins. Will definitely make these again!!

Next time I am sure it will rate higher. But as this was the first try, I did not read about how much flour you need on the surface for rolling out the dough. After 20 minutes sitting on the floured waxed paper, the dough stuck badly and I could hardly get it off to try and roll again. Then, when they finally cooked they got way too thick, Need to emphasize to roll very, very thin. Mine were still raw in the middle after 15 minutes of cooking and didn't even bend like a noodle. Some of the little, thin pieces were great. So next time will be better I am sure.
I roll the dough out. roll the flat dough into a log and cut my noodles just like my grandmother did.
These were the best noodles I have ever made. They were tender and very good in our turkey soup!
I love it its good and easy to make my family loved it
This is a wonderful recipe, my family loves it....it's my grandson's favorite...he thinks I'm a wonderful cook...it's my secret that it's all in the recipe....
Very simple recipe. Just put ingredients I bowl & used my hands to mix well, make into a dough. Pretty hard to mess up. I also doubled the recipe.

This is an excellent recipe for homemade noodles. Since the 1/2 teaspoon of baking powder was optional, I just used 1/4 teaspoon. I don't believe I ever used any before. These are so quick and easy to make, and the taste and texture is wonderful, why ever eat the dried kind again.
Amazing, I put it through my pasta maker and it made perfect spaghetti!

These are great. I used to use homemade dumplings (small) and packaged kuluski noodles to go with my homemade chicken soup but these surpass both. I did use my pasta maker which made them simple to make.

This is a nice decent recipe. I doubled it for my family of four to serve with chicken paprikash. I used the dough hook in my Kitchenaid to mix it, but found I needed to add another tablespoon of milk. Against my husband's urging, I used the old rolling pin and pizza cutter for these; he really wanted me to use the Kitchenaid's pasta attachment. Maybe next time. I didn't do the two hour dry time either, just dropped in a pot of water with some salt and chicken bouillon.
Easy to make, but nothing outstanding as far as taste.

Great recipe. Very easy. Turned out perfect.I used my pasta machine and the baking powder. Delish. Next time I will only add the baking powder when using these with chicken and noodles and will omit for things like Alfredo etc.

One of the best noodle recipes I have tried. The accompanying video is excellent. 

My noodles turned out very well, but I prefer them a bit "eggier".
These noodles are easy and turn out great

I made these noodles for turkey soup. I doubled it but only used 1/2t baking powder ...I added them to my soup ... I will cook them first next time... I will also cut them smaller for more of a dumpplingee. appearance! They are delicious and easy... I used the hint from another reviewer and used my food processor. YUM!

Doubled the recipe, but kept the baking power the same. I will make again but I want an noodle attachment for my mixer. Lol. Roll the dough out as thin as you can. Took longer than 10 minutes for my noodles to be done. I let the soup sit for another 15 minutes and the noodles were perfect.
Good basic recipe. Add herbs or pumpkin for flavor

Great recipe! Other reviewers really helped out. I rolled the dough out as thin as possible and did not allow the noodles to dry for the two hour period. I just plopped them in the soup for ten minutes and chowed down! I will use this recipe again and again!

I cheated and used a pasta machine because I made these while watching tv and only had the coffee table as a workplace. The dough was a bit hard to work with, but after a few spins through the pasta machine, it was silky and beautiful. The taste was great and it complemented my chicken noodle soup fantastically. They were even better the second day after the noodles absorbed some of the broth. Yum!
Easy and sooo good. Used them for a pot of chicken noodle soup. Even with making 3 batches of the noodles for it there were no leftovers between just 4 of us. Will make this over and over.
